title: Is a Vocoder the same as Autotune? - Quora

response.answer_text: A vocoder works by taking a musical sound input and passing it through a multi-band dynamic EQ filter, synthesizing sound. It filters out certain frequencies and allows weird sounds to be produced by instruments, an instrumentalist can “sing” with his instrument. (Similar to the voice box used for Framptons’ guitar on “do you feel like I do”) Or a voice can sound duplicated and shaded etc, like “well I remember” background on Phil Collins “In the air Tonight.” Or robotic as in many Daft Punk songs. Autotune works by pitch-shifting with a computer algorithm. It changes the frequency and sound wave to be the precise note needed. The Cher album in 1998 created a new way to use auto tune, when the producers discovered auto tune could create a robot effect when the note shifted too quickly.

No it’s not, auto tune uses computer algorithms to analyse the audio signal and assuming that you’ve set the key etc correctly makes the recorded voice be in tune, more extreme settings can result in the effect used in Cher’s ‘Believe “ single or more recent records. A vocoder uses an audio signal to modulate the input sound, usually in this case the human voice, popular examples of this are “Mr Blue Sky” by ELO and I think the first example was a song called “Sparkys electric piano” By modulating the signal we add a robotic quality to the voice, for the most effective application I have found a synthesised triangle wave to be best. So autotune helps people sing in tune. Vocoder helps them sing like robots.
